urls.title: Brazil are back – but then that's the case at every World Cup, isn't it?
urls.description: There's a sense Brazil are in better shape than in recent editions, certainly in terms of the quality of individual players available...

data.text:
Brazil are the bookies' favourites to win the World Cup. But that's been true at this point of every World Cup going back to 1994. Why did they then lose? Mental fragility at times, losing their key player - but more significantly, defending set-pieces.
https://t.co/mYLwC6T7Dp

urls.title: How Belgium got it so badly wrong at this World Cup

data.text:

urls.title: The Athletic Football Tactics Podcast: Aussie xG, Ziyech's Quality & Blame it on Lukaku: World Cup Notebook - Round 3
urls.description: The Athletic's Mark Carey, Michael Cox and Ahmed Walid pause to reflect on the conclusion of the World Cup group stages... The panel discuss the strength of England's last-16 opponents Senegal, as...

tweets.text: @Zonal_Marking On first glance it seems harsh that 4 group winners would have to play another game to get into the round of 16. And would there be a draw to determine who plays who in the pre round of 16 games? Not ideal for travelling fans (or indeed players) especially across 3 countries.
@Zonal_Marking Think the best way would be to do the same way 24 team tournaments are. So 12 groups of 4, winners and runners up go through then the 8 best third placed teams.
@Zonal_Marking So much better to keep it at 32. The more groups you have the more top teams are kept apart. No chance of Spain V Germany for example in the group stage.

@Zonal_Marking Yeah i think that's pretty good. Would also potentially add to the competitiveness of the group stage as teams who are already guaranteed top 2 after the first 2 games would be less inclined to rest players in match 3.
@Zonal_Marking Those are awful groups though, with 12x4. Accepting a 32-team knockout is probably the least worst solution (keeping 32 is the best, but that's a forlorn hope).
@Zonal_Marking I understand why this wouldn't happen, but what about groups of three where only the top team advances to the last 16?

@Zonal_Marking I know we’re wed to groups, but I’d prefer 6 pools of eight, each playing 3-4 games in the pool. The top 16 point leaders move on to the knockout. It’s not balanced, but it rewards attacking/winning over draws/surviving. EPC Rugby did it during Covid and it worked fine.

@Zonal_Marking 6 Pools of 8.
In each of those Pools there is an A Group and a B Group.
The A's play against the B's. Each team plays 4 games.
1 table of 48 teams & at the end of the Pool/Group phase, the top 16 go through to the knock out phase, with 1v16, 2v15, 3v14 etc

@Zonal_Marking Besides the unfair advantage for teams playing their final fixtures later and knowing what they need, wouldn't this also make it more complicated with the median points total to progress/fall into the wildcard round? Disciplinary points etc possibly needed as a tie-breaker

@Zonal_Marking 8 groups of 6 teams is surely the best way to manage a 48 team would cup. Top 2 go through to a R16. Every team guaranteed 5 games. Would mean you have to properly manage your squad. Can't really see any downsides? And have the euros as a half pint version with 4 groups of 6

@Zonal_Marking I agree it’s better, but you’d still have some unfair sporting advantages - teams playing later knowing exactly what they need to do to finish in the top 8 of winners.

This does have the benefit of making all the top teams play hard in all three games though I guess.

urls.title: FIFA plans to kill the drama of the World Cup group stage. Here’s how to save it
urls.description: FIFA's current plan to move from eight groups of four to 16 groups of three would be a needless detonation of two of the most thrilling weeks in all of sport.

tweets.text:
The Mexico-Saudi-Poland-Argentina drama last night was exhilarating.

It also could be the last of its kind — unless FIFA reconsiders its plan for three-team groups.

On that, + a humble proposal for four groups of 12 and a "wild-card round" in 2026: 

https://t.co/Tzimr9jaXK

Let the post-mortem begin. Suspected cause of (tournament) death: chronic imbalance and hyper-profligacy.
